abstractContent.text: This paper describes the syntax-based systems built at the University of Edinburgh for the WMT 2015 shared translation task.
We developed systems for all language pairs except French-English.

This year we focused on: translation out of En-glish using tree-to-string models; continuing to improve our English-German system ; and source-side morphological seg-mentation of Finnish using Morfessor.

introductionContent.text: This year's WMT shared translation task featured five language pairs: English paired with Czech, Finnish, French, German, and Russian.
We built syntax-based systems in both translation directions for all language pairs except English-French.
For English → German, we continued to develop our string-to-tree system, which has proven highly competitive in previous years.
Additions this year included the use of a dependency language model, an alternative tuning metric, and soft source-syntactic constraints.
For translation from English into Czech, Finnish, and Russian, we built STSG-based treeto-string systems.
Support for this type of model is a recent addition to the Moses toolkit.
In previous years, our systems have all used string-to-tree models and have only translated into English and German.
For Finnish → English, we experimented with unsupervised morphological segmentation using Morfessor 2.0 (.
For the remaining systems (Czech → English, German → English, and Russian → English), our systems were essentially the same as last year's () except for the addition of this year's training data.
